paragraph: Hence, when Hiawatha retires to rest under the pine-tree,[689] it is a dangerous step, because he resigns himself to the mother, whose garment is the garment of death (the devouring mother). As in the whale-dragon, the hero also in this situation needs a “helpful bird”; that is to say, the helpful animals, which represent the benevolent parents:“Suddenly from the boughs above him         Sang the Mama, the woodpecker;         ‘Aim your arrows, Hiawatha,         At the head of Megissogwon,         Strike the tuft of hair upon it,         At their roots the long black tresses;         There alone can he be wounded.’”
question: In the context described, why is it considered a dangerous step for Hiawatha to retire under the pine tree?
answer: It is considered a dangerous step for Hiawatha to retire under the pine tree because he resigns himself to the "mother" whose garment is the "garment of death," symbolizing danger and potential harm.
